SENT.plain: Pseudotumor cerebri (PC) is a syndrome characterized by the presence of intracranial hypertension (ICH) and no alteration in the ventricular system
Renal transplanted patients seem more susceptible to develop it due to immunosuppressive therapy
Cyclosporin (CsA) is a rare cause of PC, scarcely reported in the literature, and should be considered in the differential diagnosis of ICH and papilledema in those patients
We report the case of a 10-year-old boy, with a renal allograft for three years, on chronic use of mycophenolate mophetil (MMF), CsA, and low doses of prednisone
The patient presented with headache, vomiting, diplopia, and photophobia
Cerebrospinal fluid analysis and imaging tests were normal
After excluding secondary causes, PC was diagnosed based on the chronic use of CsA, which was then replaced by sirolimus
After that, the patient progressively improved, and the papilledema resolved in three months
